problem: Question: A European call option on a certain stock has a strike price of $30, a time to maturity of one year, and an implied volatility of 30%. A European put option on the same stock has a strike price of $30, a time to maturity of one year, and an implied volatility of 33%.Put-call parity relies solely on the lognormal assumption underlying Black-Scholes-Merton.
reasoning: From S4 and S5, put-call parity is derived from no-arbitrage and replication arguments (C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S₀) and does not depend on any specific stochastic process or the lognormal assumption of Black–Scholes–Merton. The differing implied volatilities (S6) are irrelevant to this theoretical relationship. Therefore, the statement that put-call parity relies solely on the lognormal assumption is false.

plan.title: Restate the theoretical claim to be evaluated
plan.description: Restate in precise terms the proposition: whether put-call parity relies solely on the lognormal assumption underlying the Black-Scholes-Merton model. Clarify that we need to judge if put-call parity is dependent on BSM-specific distributional assumptions.
plan.expected_output: A clear, formal reformulation of the statement whose truth value is to be assessed.
plan.result: The precise proposition to be evaluated is: "The validity of European put-call parity depends solely on, and is derived from, the lognormal stock price assumption used in the Black–Scholes–Merton model; that is, put-call parity holds because of the BSM lognormal distributional assumption and would not hold independently of it."

plan.title: Recall theoretical definition of put-call parity
plan.description: From option pricing theory, recall and write down the standard put-call parity relationship for European options on a non-dividend-paying stock (and, conceptually, its extensions with dividends or carrying costs). Emphasize its derivation origin (no-arbitrage and replication) rather than any particular stochastic process assumption.
plan.expected_output: A statement of the put-call parity formula and its conceptual basis (no-arbitrage and replicating portfolios).
plan.result: For a European call C and put P on a non-dividend-paying stock with spot price S0, strike K, maturity T, and risk-free rate r, standard put-call parity is: C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S0 (equivalently, C - P = S0 - K·e^{-rT}). It is derived from no-arbitrage and the ability to form replicating portfolios that produce identical payoffs at maturity, not from any specific stochastic process or lognormal price assumption. Extensions with dividends or carrying costs adjust S0 to its cost-of-carry/net-of-dividends value but retain the same no-arbitrage replication logic.

plan.title: Analyze dependency of put-call parity on BSM lognormal assumption
plan.description: Conceptually analyze whether the validity of put-call parity requires: (a) the BSM model, (b) continuous-time trading, or (c) a lognormal distribution for the underlying price, or whether it only requires no-arbitrage and the existence of a frictionless market with the ability to borrow/lend at the risk-free rate.
plan.expected_output: A concise determination of whether put-call parity fundamentally depends on a lognormal assumption or is model-agnostic with respect to return distribution.
plan.result: Put-call parity does not depend on the BSM lognormal assumption; it is model-agnostic and follows from no-arbitrage and replication in a frictionless market with borrowing/lending at the risk-free rate.

plan.title: Check relevance of differing implied volatilities

Confirm that implied vol differences may indicate pricing inconsistencies or volatility skew but do not alter the theoretical no-arbitrage parity relationship.
plan.expected_output: Conclusion that differing implied volatilities do not make put-call parity dependent on the BSM lognormal assumption.
plan.result: Differing implied volatilities have no bearing on the truth of the statement; they do not make put-call parity dependent on the BSM lognormal assumption.

step.title: Recall theoretical definition of put-call parity
step.description: From option pricing theory, recall and write down the standard put-call parity relationship for European options on a non-dividend-paying stock (and, conceptually, its extensions with dividends or carrying costs). Emphasize its derivation origin (no-arbitrage and replication) rather than any particular stochastic process assumption.
step.expected_output: A statement of the put-call parity formula and its conceptual basis (no-arbitrage and replicating portfolios).
step.result: For a European call C and put P on a non-dividend-paying stock with spot price S0, strike K, maturity T, and risk-free rate r, standard put-call parity is: C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S0 (equivalently, C - P = S0 - K·e^{-rT}). It is derived from no-arbitrage and the ability to form replicating portfolios that produce identical payoffs at maturity, not from any specific stochastic process or lognormal price assumption. Extensions with dividends or carrying costs adjust S0 to its cost-of-carry/net-of-dividends value but retain the same no-arbitrage replication logic.

candidates.result: For a European call C and put P on a non-dividend-paying stock with spot price S, strike K, maturity T, and risk-free rate r, put-call parity is: C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S. Equivalently, C - P = S - K·e^{-rT}. It is derived from no-arbitrage: a portfolio of (call + discounted bond) must replicate (put + stock), so they must have the same price, independent of any assumed stock-price distribution. With continuous dividends (yield q) or other carrying costs, the parity becomes C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S·e^{-qT}, again from replication and no-arbitrage, not from a specific stochastic process.
candidates.evidence: Standard option pricing theory states put-call parity as a no-arbitrage relationship between call, put, underlying, and bond positions. Its derivation uses replication arguments, requiring only frictionless markets and the ability to trade the underlying and risk-free asset, not a lognormal or BSM assumption.
assumptions_used: Underlying is a non-dividend-paying stock for the basic formula; extension to dividends uses a continuous dividend yield q.
Markets are frictionless with no arbitrage and the ability to borrow and lend at the risk-free rate.
Options are European so early exercise is not allowed.

candidates.result: For a European call C and put P on a non-dividend-paying stock with spot price S0, strike K, maturity T, and risk-free rate r, standard put-call parity is: C + K·e^{-rT} = P + S0 (equivalently, C - P = S0 - K·e^{-rT}). It is derived from no-arbitrage and the ability to form replicating portfolios that produce identical payoffs at maturity, not from any specific stochastic process or lognormal price assumption. Extensions with dividends or carrying costs adjust S0 to its cost-of-carry/net-of-dividends value but retain the same no-arbitrage replication logic.
candidates.evidence: Put-call parity comes from equating the payoffs of two portfolios (e.g., long call + bond vs. long stock + long put) that must have the same price today to avoid arbitrage. This argument depends only on no-arbitrage and replication in frictionless markets, and does not invoke the Black–Scholes–Merton lognormal assumption or any particular return distribution.
assumptions_used: Market is frictionless (no transaction costs, perfectly divisible assets).
Investors can borrow and lend at the risk-free rate r over the option’s maturity T.

Options are European style and written on a non-dividend-paying stock for the basic formula; dividend or carrying costs versions simply adjust the underlying’s present value but keep the same replication logic.

candidates.result: For a European call C and put P on a non-dividend-paying stock with current price S0, strike K, maturity T, and continuously compounded risk-free rate r, put-call parity is C - P = S0 - K * e^{-rT}. More generally, with known present value of dividends or cash flows D (or carrying costs/benefits), one form is C - P = S0 - D - K * e^{-rT}. This relationship is derived from no-arbitrage and the construction of replicating portfolios (a call plus discounted strike vs. a put plus the underlying), and does not depend on any specific stochastic process or distributional assumption such as lognormality.
candidates.evidence: Standard option pricing theory states that European put-call parity arises from equating the payoffs of two portfolios at maturity: (1) a call plus cash equal to K * e^{-rT}, and (2) a put plus one share of the underlying (adjusted for known dividends or carry). Since these portfolios have identical payoffs in all states at maturity, absence of arbitrage in frictionless markets implies their prices must be equal today, giving the parity formula. This derivation does not invoke the Black–Scholes–Merton dynamics or lognormality, only replication and no-arbitrage.
assumptions_used: Frictionless markets with no transaction costs or taxes
Ability to borrow and lend at the risk-free rate r
No default risk on the risk-free borrowing/lending
European-style options (exercise only at maturity)
Known and deterministic dividends or carrying costs, if present
No arbitrage opportunities in the market

It is derived from no-arbitrage and the ability to form replicating portfolios that produce identical payoffs at maturity, not from any specific stochastic process or lognormal price assumption. Extensions with dividends or carrying costs adjust S0 to its cost-of-carry/net-of-dividends value but retain the same no-arbitrage replication logic.
